importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating when the public was informed about the NTSB's preliminary report on the crash involving Brett James.
The date of the plane crash, which is central to the event described in the article and the investigation conducted by the NTSB.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The incident occurred on a single day, marking the precise moment of the crash and the beginning of the NTSB's investigation into the flight's events.

keyTakeAways: Brett James, a Grammy-winning songwriter, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, along with two others, when his plane entered a 'tightening spiral' during a flight to Franklin, North Carolina.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) reported that the plane, a Cirrus SR22T, had no mechanical issues, suggesting the crash resulted from a pilot or communication error.
James had requested a visual approach to runway 7, which was approved by air traffic control, but failed to change to the common traffic advisory frequency, leading to a loss of communication.
The controller attempted to communicate that James had not changed the radio frequency, but James did not respond, and no further communication occurred.
The plane flew over the runway and executed a left turn before descending into a spiral and crashing.

James was a prominent songwriter who collaborated with major artists such as Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, Keith Urban, and Kenny Chesney, and his work helped launch Carrie Underwood's career with the song 'Jesus, Take the Wheel'.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The central figure in the incident — the songwriter who died in a plane crash, which is the main subject of the article.

namedEntities.name: National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A U.S. federal agency responsible for investigating transportation accidents.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The NTSB conducted and released a preliminary report on the crash, providing the official explanation and findings regarding the cause of the accident.

namedEntities.name: Cirrus SR22T

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A major artist whose debut album featured a song co-written by Brett James, linking the songwriter to a well-known music legacy.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An American singer-songwriter and global music icon.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A high-profile collaborator of Brett James, highlighting the songwriter’s influence and reach in the music industry.

namedEntities.name: Common Traffic Advisory Frequency (CTAF)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A frequency used by pilots to report their position when no tower control is present.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The radio communication protocol that failed to be properly followed by James, contributing to the loss of situational awareness and communication between pilot and controller.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Grammy-winning songwriter Brett James, 57, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, when his Cirrus SR22T aircraft entered a 'tightening spiral' after a failed radio communication with air traffic control. Despite being cleared for a visual approach to runway 7 in Franklin, North Carolina, James did not switch to the common traffic advisory frequency and failed to respond to controller warnings. The NTSB’s preliminary report found no mechanical faults, indicating the crash resulted from a communication error. James was a highly respected songwriter who collaborated with major artists such as Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, Keith Urban, and Kenny Chesney, and whose work helped launch the career of Carrie Underwood.
title: Songwriter Brett James’ plane enters a 'tightening spiral' before crashing, NTSB says
